qas.question: What is another term for a standard or standardized dialect?
The support of what groups results in a dialect being standardized?
Along with grammars and dictionaries, what publications help a dialect to become standardized?
Standard Philippine English is a standard dialect of of what language?
Recognition from what body may help a dialect to become standardized?
What is the term for a dialect that remains unsupported by institutions?
There may be only one what associated with multiple languages?
Standard British Canadian is an example of a dialect of which language?
Australian Standard English  is an example of a dialect of which language?
Standard British Philippines is an example of a dialect of which language?

context: A <b5_0>standard dialect<b5_0/> (also known as a standardized dialect or "<a0_0>standard language<a0_0/>") is a dialect that is supported by <a1_0>institutions<a1_0/>. Such institutional support may include <a4_0>government<a4_0/> recognition or designation; presentation as being the "correct" form of a language in schools; published grammars, dictionaries, and <a2_0>textbooks<a2_0/> that set forth a correct spoken and written form; and an extensive formal literature that employs that dialect (prose, poetry, non-fiction, etc.). There may be multiple <b6_0>standard dialects<b6_0/> associated with a single language. For example, Standard American <a3_0>English<a3_0/>, Standard British English, Standard Canadian English, Standard Indian English, Standard Australian English, and Standard Philippine English may all be said to be standard dialects of the <b7_0><b8_0><b9_0>English language.
